utterances: Cardin's camp is also bringing in a lot of star power, like a recent Baltimore rally featuring former President Bill Clinton, who remains beloved in the black community.
Seventy-seven-year-old Pearlie B.
Pitt was in the front row at the rally and says Cardin's her guy.
Ms.
PEARLIE B.
PITT (Baltimore Resident): I'm for him.
He's been up on the Hill and he know the Hill front and backwards.
He didn't start yesterday.
He's seen good times and bad times, and now it's his time.
He will get in.
Pitt echoes many blacks at the Cardin rally and elsewhere, who said Steele is a good man, but they don't trust him.
But were these printers the only things in the packages?

Democrats are touting today's Washington Post poll that shows Cardin leading Steele by about 10 percent, but Republicans insist the two are in a statistical tie, and a new poll of black voters finds Cardin leading Steele, but 23 percent of them are till undecided, which means there's still an opportunity for both candidates to make their case.
Allison Keyes, NPR News, Washington.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
This past week, women's golf lost one of its pioneers.
Patty Berg, a founder of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, the LPGA, died Sunday.
She was 88 and suffered from Alzheimer's Disease.
Berg held 44 professional titles, including 15 majors, an LPGA Tour record.
Here to talk about Patty Berg's contribution to the game is golf commentator and former LPGA pro Judy Rankin.
She joins us from her home in Midland, Texas.
Take us back to the late '40s, when Berg and at least 12 other women were trying to form this new ladies golf tour, what ended up to be the LPGA.
Ms.
JUDY Ms. RANKIN (Former Golf Pro): To the best of my knowledge, through knowing a little bit of the organization's history, these women played for very little money in some very small places.
They kind of refused to give up.
They stuck together.
But I think they were also, aside from just very good players, you had to be a little bit showman at that point in time, and no one in women's golf has ever been better at that than Patty Berg.
What did she do?
I know she was famous for her clinics.
They were called the Patty Berg Hit Parade.
Is this right?
It was actually the LPGA Swing Parade.

As time went on and the LPGA Tour was on more solid footing, one of the things that the LPGA committed to their sponsors was that they would put on a clinic at every tournament site, and Patty was always the host.
And if you were a player, and you got a little note on your locker to be at the clinic with your seven iron, you didn't even think about not being there.
And she understood the everyday golfer's frustration with the game, and she could make great sport of it.
And while teaching people she could make them laugh.
Do you remember any of her jokes that she would tell over and over?
One little thing I remember is she would say, well, yesterday I was here and the pin was there, and today I was there and the pin was here.
And so that's sort of the frustration of the everyday golfer.
The shot that would have worked yesterday you have today and so on and so forth.
How was she regarded by the women golfers who came after her?
Oh, I think Patty Berg was a little bit of an icon, really.
She was, you know, one of the names you knew growing up, and there weren't very many names to know at that time.
And for the kids who are kids today, because Patty stayed so involved with the LPGA and with golf generally, they are all very aware of what Patty did and who she was.

And it was a very sad time for women's golf when she made it public a couple of years ago that she had Alzheimer's and that she probably would be dropping out of a lot of the activities that she had tried to take part in, even though her health had been ailing for 10 years.
Former LPGA pro and golf commentator Judy Rankin.
Thanks for talking with us.
Thank you.
Nice to talk to you.
Patty Berg was buried yesterday in Fort Myers, Florida.
The United Kingdom has a new prime minister.
The ruling Conservative Party made the announcement in London this morning.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Therefore, I give notice that Boris Johnson is elected as the leader of the Conservative and Unionist Party.
(APPLAUSE)
That was the moment it happened.
NPR's Joanna Kakissis is in London watching it all unfold.
Good morning, Joanna.
Good morning, Rachel.
So the big announcement came.
Boris Johnson then addressed the country.
What did he say?
So he talked about unifying the Conservative Party.
He said it's a party that has always known what's best for the country and has delivered it over the past 200 years.
And he believes Brexit is what's best for the U.K.
right now, even though Britain is deeply divided over it and there are dire economic warnings about exiting the European Union without a deal.

So he said this morning in his speech, he said he read a speech - I'm sorry - he said he read a piece in a British newspaper this morning describing the daunting circumstances facing the new prime minister.
And this was his response.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Well, I look at you this morning.
And I ask myself, do you look daunted?
Do you feel daunted?
I don't think - I don't think you look remotely daunted to me.
And I think that we know that we can do it and that the people of this country are trusting in us to do it.
And we know that we will do it.
So he sounds like a man who is very prepared to do this with what he's said repeatedly is a can-do attitude.
But does he have a mandate?
I mean, we should remember he was selected by a ballot vote within his own Conservative Party.
But only 160,000 people in the party voted.
So is he capable of unifying the country?
So that's the big question right now.
And there are concerns that he does not - that he's not capable of doing that.
He's a divisive figure here in Britain.
A lot of people find his style very off-putting.
They find him unprepared.
They find that he makes decisions based on his gut and not on the details.
And this is - you know, this is an issue - Brexit is an issue that needs details.
It needs somebody who is interested in process and who's not interested in just the showboating aspect of politics, which Boris Johnson's detractors say he's more fond of.
So yeah, that's a big question mark right now.
So Brexit - I mean, let's just talk about this for a minute.
This is the issue right now.
This is the problem that defeated Theresa May.
It will now undoubtedly vex, to some degree, her successor Boris Johnson.
He claims he's the one to make it happen.
How much of his hard-line approach to Brexit had to do with his selection as the new prime minister?
How many people typically would live in a Green House?
Well, you know, Conservative Party members who voted for Brexit were really tired of this process taking so long.
It was just long, drawn-out - you know, bewildering.
And you know, they just want it to end.
They want a timetable.
They want a specific timetable.
They want to know when it's going to happen, how it's going to happen.
And Boris Johnson has said - has promised that he's going to do it by October 30.
We're going to - he has said, we are going to exit the European Union by - that the U.K.
is going to exit the European Union by October 31, do or die.
And that was very appealing to Conservative Party members who are just tired of sort of this never-ending Brexit story.
So those who don't like Boris Johnson in the U.K.
and also don't like President Trump liken Johnson to the American president.
They are both political showmen; they're both populists.
But there are differences, as well, between the two leaders.
Are there not?
Yes.
You know, Boris Johnson - and we saw this today in the speech - he's known for making very funny, highly literate, very smart speeches.
He's very politically savvy.
He's very well-read.
He went to Britain's top boarding school, Eton.
He went to Oxford University.
He...
He is an elite.
He is absolutely one of Britain's elite.
And he cultivates this everyman image of being chronically underprepared and even bumbling.
And that's what appeals to the British.
He's kind of the closest thing to a celebrity politician here.
But at heart, he is a very well-educated, very privileged and very smart guy.
And controversial, although a long experience in politics - the mayor of London and served as the foreign secretary under Prime Minister Theresa May.
Joanna Kakissis watching all of this in London.
We appreciate it, Joanna.
Thank you.
Thank you, Rachel.

And I'm Madeleine Brand.
